bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [March 1941]

div1.p: Truby discusses the plan to commission a painting of the Yellow Fever Board, including Finlay. He will ask Andrus and England for verification of locations and hopes his letter to Ramos was sufficient.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [March 1941]

opener.dateline:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
March 1941

div1.p:
Yours of the 4th re the Wyeth painting
came this a.m. Thank's for the reprint on
gout.

I dont think you read my letter to
Mr Kellogg carefully;- First, I was not
commenting on the painting of the ward buildings,
(They were painted when constructed) but on the officers
quarters which were built in July '99- Second, I
think my remarks are clear about perpetuating
distortions which are controversial. There
would be no controversy about a group scene
such as I suggested. The more I think of it
the more I am in favor of my suggestion.
I think it would be a wonderful thing to
have the whole group (Wood, Finlay, Reed Board,
and all Roll of Honor men) reproduced. That
would mean something! I do hope that
Mr. Kellogg will not bex too hasty in
deciding on the matter, for, with a little
patience and collaboration, the possibilities
for something very good, are wonderful-

I am of course merely trying to be
helpful in a construction way. I am
too busy to take this out to be typed, but
if you think it with while please quote
AC
T
me when you write to Mr Kellogg-
I am anxious to know what my old
friend, Jefferson Randolph Kean, has to say
about the picture. He has good ideas, but
for some reason, I feel he will may not
concur with me re General Wood. However,
he knows, as you know and as I know
that the Reed board would never have undertaken
the experimentation on human subjects without
the encouragement and full support of Wood.

I will inclose herewith the papers
etc. re. your report to Dr. Ramos, I
would like to keep some of the photos and
will hold them here pending your approval.

The 1902 map is splendid. The Perez model
is still a mess. I suggest you send the enlarged
1902 map to Col. Willis and suggest that he pay
remove the buildings from the least of the model
and place them on a flat piece of ground in
accordance with the scale on the small map. The
enlarged map scale can be readily estimated, roughly
it seems 70 ft=1 inch. Then if Col. Willis
will make a photo. of the layout it would be
worth something. The 1907 map shows the contours
and would help in showing the grades especially
in the Western part of the hospital grounds &
(y.f. hosp.)

I dont know where the key to the 1902
map can be found. Probably the D.M. g.o.
can find it in Major Baker's report.
On page 48 of his report, (in the 1901
report of Gen. Wood) you will note that
“Prints were forwarded.” Two of these were
“Columbia Bks.” probably maps & In case
you find no trace of a key I suggest
that you send copies of the map to
Capt. England and Andrus for verification
for I know that their memories are still
keen and they knew the place intimately.

Please do not go to the trouble of
making photostats of your W. & J. talk.
I will gladly wait for reprints until
you have the article republished.

I hope you have a successful
and enjoyable trip to Cuba- I like
your suggestions re memoralizing Camp
Lazear and the place where Lazear died,
especially the latter. It is a wonderful
site and a five building there housing
the old building no. 1. meets my ideas
exactly. While you are in Havana you
may find that the Cuban Army authorities have
some good photos. of the Columbia Bks Hospital
buildings. They used them for some years
AC
T
If Dr. Ramos approves your plans
it will be very important to be sure
about the exact spot of Lazear's death. I
am on the track of the attendants who worked
on his case and before I finish think
I can tell you the exact building where he died.
I believe from info I now have that it
was either 116 or 115 on the the 1902 map.
It will help me if you can send me
about 3 copies of the enlarged 1902 map so
I can send them around to the men.
I have definitely found out that Andrus was
in 116. I got this “dope” from Lambert. The latter
unfortunately was not on Lazear's case. By the time
you return I will probably have more info.
So if the Cuban govt. wants “expert” advice
on the locations, arrange at a trip for me
sorry I can't be there with you on this trip.
I wonder if Dr. Sawyer could not
interest the Rockefeller foundation in assisting
financially in a suitable memorial on the
y.f. site. I am sure they are deeply interested in
everything that pertains to the work in Cuba-

Please do not forget to send me the maps before
you leave Rochester-

If I left anything out of the letter
to Dr. Ramos advise me and I will
be glad to add whatever you suggest.
